content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: SubRip
Meta's AI translation remakes Reels in your language
entries.snippet:
Meta has introduced a new AI-powered feature that automatically translates, dubs, and lip-syncs Reels on Facebook and Instagram into different languages, currently supporting English, Spanish, Hindi, and Portuguese. This enhancement allows users to experience videos as if they were originally created in their native language, complete with voice cloning that mimics the original speaker‚Äôs tone and cadence, and optional lip-syncing for added realism. While this service isn't available for all users, Facebook creators with over 1,000 followers and all public Instagram accounts in supported countries can access the feature for free.

Clearly labeled with a "Translated with Meta AI" tag, viewers have the option to disable translations or keep the original audio. This move builds on Meta‚Äôs history of multilingual content tools like auto-captions and subtitled Stories. However, it marks the company‚Äôs first use of AI for voice cloning and lip-syncing, giving Meta a potential advantage over competitors like YouTube and TikTok, who offer translation overlays and captions but not real-time dubbing with voice sync. The innovation aims to make short-form content more globally accessible and culturally inclusive.

entries.title: Meta's AI translation tool can dub your Instagram videos
entries.snippet: Meta is expanding its AI translation tool to more users on Facebook and Instagram, allowing automatic dubbing of reels between English and Spanish. The tool utilizes AI to generate voiceovers matching the user‚Äôs voice and mouth movements. To use it, creators can activate the "Translate voices with Meta AI" toggle before publishing a reel. The feature also supports optional lip-syncing and allows review before sharing. Translated reels are automatically shown to users in their preferred language and are marked with a disclosure tag indicating AI translation. The rollout is currently available to Facebook creators with at least 1,000 followers and all public Instagram accounts.

entries.title: Facebook-parent Meta unveils AI voice translations for Reels, starting with English and Spanish
entries.snippet: Meta has launched a new AI-powered translation feature for content creators on Facebook and Instagram Reels. The tool, known as Meta AI translations, initially supports English and Spanish and aims to include more languages in the future. It allows creators to automatically dub and lip-sync their videos into another language, facilitating better global reach and accessibility. According to Meta, the feature is free and helps users connect with international audiences more effectively by delivering content in the viewer's native language. This innovation is expected to significantly enhance creators' ability to grow global followings.

v.title: Google Meet can translate what you say into other languages
v.snippet:
Google is introducing real-time speech translation in Google Meet, leveraging its Gemini AI technology. This new feature, revealed during Google's I/O event, allows spoken words to be translated into a conversation partner's preferred language while preserving the original speaker‚Äôs voice, tone, and expression. Initially, translations are available only between English and Spanish, but Google plans to expand to Italian, German, and Portuguese soon.

The translation feature is rolling out in beta for users subscribed to the AI Pro plan or the premium AI Ultra subscription, which costs $249.99 per month. In a demonstration, Google showed how English and Spanish speakers can seamlessly communicate, with Meet providing real-time dubbed translations reflecting natural vocal inflections. This development places Google in competition with Microsoft Teams, which launched a similar AI translation feature earlier in the year.

entries.title: EVE: Towards End-to-End Video Subtitle Extraction with Vision-Language Models

v.title: MeetDot: Videoconferencing with Live Translation Captions
Google Translate brings real-time speech translations to any headphones
v.snippet:
Google Translate has introduced a major update allowing live speech translations on all headphones, not just Google's Pixel Buds. Available in beta starting today, the feature supports over 70 languages and requires only a compatible Android phone with the Translate app‚Äîunlike Apple‚Äôs version, which is limited to AirPods. This expansion marks a shift towards broader accessibility for real-time translation.

Additionally, Google Translate is improving text translations with the help of its Gemini AI, which enhances the accuracy of idioms and slang, offering more natural interpretations of phrases like ‚Äústealing my thunder.‚Äù The update also expands the Practice feature‚Äîsimilar to Duolingo‚Äîto 20 more countries and supports more languages. This interactive learning tool provides personalized sessions that adapt to users‚Äô language levels.

The live translation update is rolling out on Android in the US, Mexico, and India, with an iOS version expected next year. Enhanced text translations are also now available on both Android and iOS, as well as the web. The Practice feature remains in beta and may be limited to some users.
